Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge correctly applied the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Respondent was physically present in Canada for only 406 days over four years; primary life maintained in Hong Kong
Court_Ruling: Citizenship Judge erred in fact and law
Defendant_Behavior: Extended absences from Canada, maintaining primary residence and life in Hong Kong
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet physical residency requirement for citizenship
Assessment_Factor: Nature and duration of absences, ties to Canada vs. foreign country
Procedural_Issue: Hearings conducted via videoconference after respondent's failure to appear
Credibility_Assessment: Citizenship Judge's conclusion on temporary nature of absences found unreasonable
Evidence_Used: Record of physical presence (406 days), evidence of residence and activities in Hong Kong
Application_Basis: Koo test for determining temporary absence
Evidence_Assessed: Duration of stay in Canada, strength of connections to Hong Kong
Governing_Rule: Applicant must be physically present in Canada for at least 1,095 days within a four-year period
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge failed to consider evidence that respondent’s life was primarily based in Hong Kong
Harm_Assessment: Risk of granting citizenship to individual not meeting法定 residency requirements
Cause_Description: Minister appealed citizenship approval due to insufficient residency in Canada
Evidence_Handling: Court reviewed record and found judge overlooked key evidence
Evidence_Issues: Dispute over interpretation of temporary vs. permanent absences
Evidence_Assessment: Judge’s assessment of temporary absence deemed unreasonable
Decision_Rationale: Absences were not temporary; primary life remained in Hong Kong
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to properly weigh evidence of foreign residence
